newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium's Verplaetse backs Duisenberg for ECB job.
newsitem.headline: Belgium's Verplaetse backs Duisenberg for ECB job.

text.p: Belgian central bank governor Alfons Verplaetse was quoted as saying on Tuesday the presidency of the planned European Central Bank (ECB) should go to a small nation and he would like his Dutch counterpart Wim Duisenberg in the job.

"If it depended on me, yes (Duisenberg should get the job)," Verplaetse told Le Soir newspaper in an interview. "Honestly I believe the presidency should go to a small country following, for example, the tradition of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) in Basle."

Verplaetse is due to replace Duisenberg as president of the BIS on July 1 when Duisenberg takes over from Belgian Alexandre Lamfalussy as president of the European Monetary Institute (EMI), the ECB's forerunner.
"A big country has always ambitions. But we have to come to a consensus," Verplaetse added in response to a question about reported French opposition to Duisenberg getting the ECB job.
European Union leaders are due to decide on the president of the ECB in 1998 after they have chosen the countries that will take part in economic and monetary union (EMU).
